Man Utd schoolboys and parents 'bemused' by Sir Jim Ratcliffe outburst blaming academy for 'slipping'
Source: Goal.com    Published: 2025-10-24 16:26:39

Manchester United minority owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe's latest rant against the club's academy has left the Red Devils schoolboys and parents 'bemused'. Ratcliffe has taken a ruthless approach since buying stakes at the Premier League club in 2024. He has let go of hundreds of staff in a major job-cutting drive in a bid to tackle the club's financial condition.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


U-17 WNT Wins Group C with Dominant Win over Norway in 2025 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup
Source: US Soccer    Published: 2025-10-24 16:21:28

Get unrivaled matchday access SALÉ, Morocco (Oct. 24, 2025) -- The U.S Under-17 Women's National Team defeated Norway 5-0 to win Group C at the 2025 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup. It was the second time the USA has won its group at this tournament (with 2022 in India being the other) but the first time the U.S. U-17s have won all three group games. Three National Women's Soccer League players scored goals as forwards KK Ream (Utah Royals), Ellie Kocher and Micayla Johnson (Chicago Stars) and midfielder Mak Whitham (Gotham FC) each tallied their first goals of the tournament while Nyanya Touray came off the bench to score her fourth. The USA will now face the third-place team from Group A, B or F on Tuesday, Oct. 28 at 11:30 a.m. ET on FS2. The USA has scored 13 goals in group play in this tournament, matching its record for most goals during the group stage at the FIFA U-17 WWC, which was set in India in 2022, but that group stage included an 8-0 win over India. U.S. head coach Katie Schoepfer made six changes to the starting XI from the second group match, a 5-2 win over China PR that clinched a berth in the Round of 16 with one match -- this one against Norway -- remaining. Schoepfer kept the same back line and changed five of the six midfielders/forwards, and the USA scored five goals in a game for the second time in the tournament. Goalkeeper Peyton Trayer got the nod in the nets for the USA after Evan O'Steen had started the first two matches. Trayer earned her first World Cup shutout. Norway, needing a win to have any chance of advancing in a tournament that sends four third-place teams to the knockout round, fell far short. It took the USA just under six minutes to score as Ream dribbled into the left side of the penalty area, made a bit of space for herself to shoot and smacked her left-footed shot off the right post and in from 16 yards out. For Ream, the youngest goal scorer in NWSL history when she tallied on Aug. 29 for the Utah Royals at 16 years and 52 days old, it was her first goal of this tournament. It was also the USA's fastest goal yet of the tournament. The USA doubled its lead in the 49th minute and effectively put the game away as the young Americans were even more dominant in the second half. Midfielder Scottie Antonucci played a ball to Kocher just above the penalty box on the right. Kocher beat Norway defender Lea Ellingsen with a quick cut to her right as she dribbled into the penalty area and then struck her shot on the ground inside the left post from just above the corner of the six-yard box. It was Kocher's first goal of the tournament as well. Midfielder Nyanya Touray entered the match in the 61st minute and made an immediate impact, scoring in the 63rd. The goal came as Ream got around the defense into the left side of the penalty area and cut a pass back to Touray, who perfectly timed her run and finished with the inside of her right foot from 10 yards out. The goal momentarily tied Touray for the lead in the Golden Boot race with four goals so far in the tournament, and she of course leads the USA in scoring. The USA made it two goals in a two-minute span when a nice attack down the right side saw Johnson, who came on in the 62nd minute, cross from the right side to Ream, who sent a header on goal. Norway goalkeeper Sara Holte, who came on at halftime, saved the shot but spilled the ball right at the feet of Whitham, who smashed the rebound into the net from close range to make it 4-0 in the 64th. The USA finished the scoring in the 80th minute and this time it was Johnson. She played a give-and-go with substitute Lauren Malsom in the right side of the penalty box and then rolled her shot off the left post and in from about 16 yards out. Trayer was called into action in the 30th minute as Norway forward Christina Herseth got behind the U.S. defense into the left side of the penalty area drove a high shot at goal. Trayer pushed the ball away, but the rebound fell to another Norway attacker and Trayer had to save that shot with a dive to her left. The USA utilized the Video Support System in the 38th minute, asking for a penalty kick review as Celia Halvorsen bundled into outside back Sydney Schmidt in the right side of the penalty area as both battled for a cross. After video review, the referee denied the request. Whitham had two good chances to score inside the final five minutes of the first half. In the 42nd minute she intercepted a back pass deep inside the penalty box, but she was in close quarters with the Norway goalkeeper Maria Kroken, who stole the ball off her feet. In the 45th minute, Schmidt made a great dribbling run, advanced the ball 40 yards down the left side and played Ream on the wing. Ream crossed to Whitham inside the six-yard box, but the USA's youngest player at 15 years of age put her close range shot over the bar. Whitham would get her goal later in the game. Norway exited its first FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup without scoring a goal. USA – KK Ream, 6th minute: The USA benefited from a Norway turnover in the back as Ream dribbled in the left channel and struck a left-footed shot from just inside the penalty area off the right post and in past the diving Norway goalkeeper. USA 1, NOR 0 USA – Ellie Kocher (Scottie Antonucci), 49th minute: Antonucci played a short pass to Kocher just above the penalty box on the right. She took on her defender one-on-one, scorched her to the outside, and then drove her shot on the ground inside the left post from just above the corner of the six-yard box. USA 2, NOR 0 USA – Nyanya Touray (KK Ream), 63rd minute: Touray immediately sparked the USA after coming off the bench, scoring seconds after subbing on. Touray ran onto a perfect cut back pass into the seam from Ream and finished with the inside of her right foot from 10 yards. USA 3, NOR 0 USA – Mak Whitham, 64th minute: Whitham capitalized on a mistake from the Norway goalkeeper who dropped KK Ream's header just in front of the goal and the 15-year-old made her pay, blasting the ball into the net from close range. USA 4, NOR 0 USA – Micayla Johnson, 80th minute: Johnson and fellow sub Lauren Malsom played a give-and-go in the right side of the box which set up Johnson to roll her shot off the left post and in from about 16 yards out and become the first American player to score in two FIFA U-17 Women's World Cups. USA 5, NOR 0 – FINAL Match: United States Under-17 Women's National Team vs. Norway Date: Oct. 24, 2025 Competition: 2025 FIFA Under-17 Women's World Cup – Group C Venue: Mohammed VI Football Academy (Pitch 3); Salé, Morocco Attendance: 500 Kickoff: Noon local (9 a.m. ET) Weather: 81 and sunny Lineups: USA: 12-Peyton Trayer; 2-Cali O'Neill, 4-Pearl Cecil, 5-Meila Brewer, 3-Sydney Schmidt; 8-Chloe Sadler (16-Anastasia Showler-Little, 78), 6-Scottie Antonucci (Capt.), 10-Jaiden Rodriguez (7-Nyanya Touray, 61); 20-Ellie Kocher (17-Micayla Johnson, 62), 18-Mak Whitham (9-Lauren Malsom, 67), 19-KK Ream Substitutes not used: 1-Evan O'Steen, 11-Maddie DiMaria, 13-Olivia Robinson, 14-Natalie Chudowsky, 15-Riley Kennedy, 21-Ella McNeal Head coach: Katie Schoepfer NOR: 1-Maria Kroken (12-Sara Holte, 46), 4-Millie Flo (Capt.) (3-Nathalie Skeide, 77), 5-Lea Ellingsen, 6-Aida Berg, 7-Tomine Enger, 11-Christina Herseth, 15-Celia Halvorsen (10-Heidi Halbmayr, 60), 16-Maren Fuglas, 17-Isa Lund (18-Maria Hagen, 77), 19-Sunniva Hjertvik (2-Ebba Niss, 67), 20-Elida Kolbjornsen Substitutes not used: 9-Julie Steen, 13-Sandra Pallesen-Nygard, 14-Amalie Lia, 21-Tril Sand Head coach: Eline Kulstad-Torneus Stats Summary: USA / NOR Shots: 13 / 8 Shots on Goal: 9 / 3 Saves: 3 / 4 Corner Kicks: 3 / 0 Fouls: 4 / 9 Offside: 2 / 0 Officials: Referee: Milagros Arruela (PER)  AR1: Mariana Aquino (PER) AR2: Vera Yupanqui (PER) Fourth Official: Lizzet Garcia (MEX)
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


U-17 WNT Wins Group C with Dominant Win over Norway in 2025 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup
Source: US Soccer    Published: 2025-10-24 16:21:28

Get unrivaled matchday access SALÉ, Morocco (Oct. 24, 2025) -- The U.S Under-17 Women's National Team defeated Norway 5-0 to win Group C at the 2025 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup. It was the second time the USA has won its group at this tournament (with 2022 in India being the other) but the first time the U.S. U-17s have won all three group games. Three National Women's Soccer League players scored goals as forwards KK Ream (Utah Royals), Ellie Kocher and Micayla Johnson (Chicago Stars) and midfielder Mak Whitham (Gotham FC) each tallied their first goals of the tournament while Nyanya Touray came off the bench to score her fourth. The USA will now face the third-place team from Group A, B or F on Tuesday, Oct. 28 at 11:30 a.m. ET on FS2. The USA has scored 13 goals in group play in this tournament, matching its record for most goals during the group stage at the FIFA U-17 WWC, which was set in India in 2022, but that group stage included an 8-0 win over India. U.S. head coach Katie Schoepfer made six changes to the starting XI from the second group match, a 5-2 win over China PR that clinched a berth in the Round of 16 with one match -- this one against Norway -- remaining. Schoepfer kept the same back line and changed five of the six midfielders/forwards, and the USA scored five goals in a game for the second time in the tournament. Goalkeeper Peyton Trayer got the nod in the nets for the USA after Evan O'Steen had started the first two matches. Trayer earned her first World Cup shutout. Norway, needing a win to have any chance of advancing in a tournament that sends four third-place teams to the knockout round, fell far short. It took the USA just under six minutes to score as Ream dribbled into the left side of the penalty area, made a bit of space for herself to shoot and smacked her left-footed shot off the right post and in from 16 yards out. For Ream, the youngest goal scorer in NWSL history when she tallied on Aug. 29 for the Utah Royals at 16 years and 52 days old, it was her first goal of this tournament. It was also the USA's fastest goal yet of the tournament. The USA doubled its lead in the 49th minute and effectively put the game away as the young Americans were even more dominant in the second half. Midfielder Scottie Antonucci played a ball to Kocher just above the penalty box on the right. Kocher beat Norway defender Lea Ellingsen with a quick cut to her right as she dribbled into the penalty area and then struck her shot on the ground inside the left post from just above the corner of the six-yard box. It was Kocher's first goal of the tournament as well. Midfielder Nyanya Touray entered the match in the 61st minute and made an immediate impact, scoring in the 63rd. The goal came as Ream got around the defense into the left side of the penalty area and cut a pass back to Touray, who perfectly timed her run and finished with the inside of her right foot from 10 yards out. The goal momentarily tied Touray for the lead in the Golden Boot race with four goals so far in the tournament, and she of course leads the USA in scoring. The USA made it two goals in a two-minute span when a nice attack down the right side saw Johnson, who came on in the 62nd minute, cross from the right side to Ream, who sent a header on goal. Norway goalkeeper Sara Holte, who came on at halftime, saved the shot but spilled the ball right at the feet of Whitham, who smashed the rebound into the net from close range to make it 4-0 in the 64th. The USA finished the scoring in the 80th minute and this time it was Johnson. She played a give-and-go with substitute Lauren Malsom in the right side of the penalty box and then rolled her shot off the left post and in from about 16 yards out. Trayer was called into action in the 30th minute as Norway forward Christina Herseth got behind the U.S. defense into the left side of the penalty area drove a high shot at goal. Trayer pushed the ball away, but the rebound fell to another Norway attacker and Trayer had to save that shot with a dive to her left. The USA utilized the Video Support System in the 38th minute, asking for a penalty kick review as Celia Halvorsen bundled into outside back Sydney Schmidt in the right side of the penalty area as both battled for a cross. After video review, the referee denied the request. Whitham had two good chances to score inside the final five minutes of the first half. In the 42nd minute she intercepted a back pass deep inside the penalty box, but she was in close quarters with the Norway goalkeeper Maria Kroken, who stole the ball off her feet. In the 45th minute, Schmidt made a great dribbling run, advanced the ball 40 yards down the left side and played Ream on the wing. Ream crossed to Whitham inside the six-yard box, but the USA's youngest player at 15 years of age put her close range shot over the bar. Whitham would get her goal later in the game. Norway exited its first FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup without scoring a goal. USA – KK Ream, 6th minute: The USA benefited from a Norway turnover in the back as Ream dribbled in the left channel and struck a left-footed shot from just inside the penalty area off the right post and in past the diving Norway goalkeeper. USA 1, NOR 0 USA – Ellie Kocher (Scottie Antonucci), 49th minute: Antonucci played a short pass to Kocher just above the penalty box on the right. She took on her defender one-on-one, scorched her to the outside, and then drove her shot on the ground inside the left post from just above the corner of the six-yard box. USA 2, NOR 0 USA – Nyanya Touray (KK Ream), 63rd minute: Touray immediately sparked the USA after coming off the bench, scoring seconds after subbing on. Touray ran onto a perfect cut back pass into the seam from Ream and finished with the inside of her right foot from 10 yards. USA 3, NOR 0 USA – Mak Whitham, 64th minute: Whitham capitalized on a mistake from the Norway goalkeeper who dropped KK Ream's header just in front of the goal and the 15-year-old made her pay, blasting the ball into the net from close range. USA 4, NOR 0 USA – Micayla Johnson, 80th minute: Johnson and fellow sub Lauren Malsom played a give-and-go in the right side of the box which set up Johnson to roll her shot off the left post and in from about 16 yards out and become the first American player to score in two FIFA U-17 Women's World Cups. USA 5, NOR 0 – FINAL Match: United States Under-17 Women's National Team vs. Norway Date: Oct. 24, 2025 Competition: 2025 FIFA Under-17 Women's World Cup – Group C Venue: Mohammed VI Football Academy (Pitch 3); Salé, Morocco Attendance: 500 Kickoff: Noon local (9 a.m. ET) Weather: 81 and sunny Lineups: USA: 12-Peyton Trayer; 2-Cali O'Neill, 4-Pearl Cecil, 5-Meila Brewer, 3-Sydney Schmidt; 8-Chloe Sadler (16-Anastasia Showler-Little, 78), 6-Scottie Antonucci (Capt.), 10-Jaiden Rodriguez (7-Nyanya Touray, 61); 20-Ellie Kocher (17-Micayla Johnson, 62), 18-Mak Whitham (9-Lauren Malsom, 67), 19-KK Ream Substitutes not used: 1-Evan O'Steen, 11-Maddie DiMaria, 13-Olivia Robinson, 14-Natalie Chudowsky, 15-Riley Kennedy, 21-Ella McNeal Head coach: Katie Schoepfer NOR: 1-Maria Kroken (12-Sara Holte, 46), 4-Millie Flo (Capt.) (3-Nathalie Skeide, 77), 5-Lea Ellingsen, 6-Aida Berg, 7-Tomine Enger, 11-Christina Herseth, 15-Celia Halvorsen (10-Heidi Halbmayr, 60), 16-Maren Fuglas, 17-Isa Lund (18-Maria Hagen, 77), 19-Sunniva Hjertvik (2-Ebba Niss, 67), 20-Elida Kolbjornsen Substitutes not used: 9-Julie Steen, 13-Sandra Pallesen-Nygard, 14-Amalie Lia, 21-Tril Sand Head coach: Eline Kulstad-Torneus Stats Summary: USA / NOR Shots: 13 / 8 Shots on Goal: 9 / 3 Saves: 3 / 4 Corner Kicks: 3 / 0 Fouls: 4 / 9 Offside: 2 / 0 Officials: Referee: Milagros Arruela (PER)  AR1: Mariana Aquino (PER) AR2: Vera Yupanqui (PER) Fourth Official: Lizzet Garcia (MEX)

Jazwares Partners with FIFA for Official World Cup 2026 Plush Collection
Source: License Global    Published: 2025-10-24 15:36:51

Toy company to produce mascot plush and collectibles for the tournament across North America. October 24, 2025 Jazwares has been named the official worldwide plush licensee for the FIFA World Cup 2026. The toy company, which makes the Squishmallows brand, will produce an officially licensed product range including plush items, wearables and novelties for the tournament. The collection will feature the official mascot and competition-themed products designed for participating countries and their supporters. The FIFA World Cup 2026 will be hosted across 16 cities in North America from June 11 to July 19. The 39-day tournament will include three core mascot plushes representing the host countries of Canada, Mexico and the U.S., along with other items. Limited-edition collectibles will be available only at select events. "The FIFA World Cup is more than a competition; it's a stage where history is written and the world comes together," says Sam Ferguson, senior vice president, global licensing, Jazwares. "To see our creations become part of that story is an honor beyond measure. Partnering with FIFA enables us to do what we do best on the grandest stage imaginable: inspire joy, spark imagination, and create first-of-their-kind keepsakes that will live in the hearts and homes of fans everywhere. From the official mascot designs to celebrating the sport's classic iconography, this collection is our tribute to the passion, pride, and unity that define the game." Related:10 Minutes With … Jazwares on What Makes IPs Stick The official FIFA World Cup 2026 product collection from Jazwares will debut in June 2026, with products available in select retail stores and online worldwide. A complete lineup of products will be revealed early next year. Through its print edition, website, daily e-newsletter and event publications, License Global reaches more than 150,000 executives and professionals in all major markets. The magazine also serves as the official publication for the sector's trade events, which include Licensing Expo, Brand Licensing Europe, France Licensing Day, Licensing for Retail Conference, Licensing Expo Japan, Licensing Expo Shanghai and the Licensing Leadership Summit. Football: From first goal to final goodbye: Alex Morgan's farewell to U.S. Women's National Team
Source: Olympics.com    Published: 2025-10-24 15:28:00

In the same place she scored her first senior international goal, Alex Morgan bids a final farewell to the USWNT having left the sport in a better place than she found it. Fifteen years ago, Alex Morgan introduced herself to U.S. football fans with her first goal in Chester, Pennsylvania. On Thursday (23 October), the recently retired forward waved goodbye from the same place. The arc of her phenomenal career, in which she bloomed into a global icon, had come full circle—ending where it began. “It was one of the best moments that I can remember with the team because it was really the start of something great for me,” she told U.S. Soccer. “It was a great first goal and I'm excited to be back at the stadium to be honoured this way so many years later.” Few could have predicted just how much of a global powerhouse the then 21-year-old would go on to become. Achievements on the pitch speak volumes – multiple World Cup titles, Olympic medals, and 123 goals in 224 appearances. Yet it was what she did off the pitch that really kick-started a legacy which would send the women's game soaring worldwide. Morgan's activism is another aspect that sets her apart. Her fight for better conditions domestically and on the national team has ensured that the California native retires from a sport in much better condition than when she came into it. Start 2026 in Italy! The Olympic Winter Games are just a TICKET away! 🏂❄️🎿 Sign-up for reminders of ticket releases and all the latest news of your favourite national Olympic teams and athletes trying to qualify! 🎫 Alex Morgan scores her first USWNT goal in Chester, Pennsylvania in 2010 In the run-up to honouring Morgan, the current head coach of the USWNT—Emma Hayes—had plenty to say about the player who defined a period of this team's success. The English coach called for recognition of a career that transcended all expectations, winning it all on home soil and in Europe. “There was nothing she didn't achieve; she was a player that epitomised everything this program is about,” Hayes said of the iconic no.13. “She is an unbelievable credit to her family because her drive, her desire, her determination to prove herself at the highest level is second to none. “You can't go anywhere in this country without them talking about Alex Morgan, and I think the sport should show a lot of gratitude to that. She is, without question, one of the most recognisable faces in our sport.” For Morgan, however, nothing matters more than people recognising her as someone who fought on and off the pitch – for herself and for her teammates. “I would love for people to know that I was as dedicated on the field as I was off the field,” she expressed to TNT Sports. “Off the field, that was fighting for women's sports, fighting for girls to have equal opportunity, fighting for and prioritising my family. “Just know that I fought for my team on the pitch and I fought for myself and my team off it.” Alex Morgan wins the World Cup with the USWNT in 2015 Morgan bows out of the playing side with so much pride for everything she has achieved over the last 15 years. Given her mainstay status, fans can expect to still see her in and around anything involving women's sports as she aims to continue driving them to the very top. That includes her work with the San Diego Wave in the NWSL, where the striker spent the last few years of her playing career. “I am part of the ownership group and intend to have an active role,” she told FIFA. “I am continuing to stay active in other ways like with my media company, which focuses on women's sports and highlights female athletes in general. “There are always threads that keep me busy and connected to the sport—I also have a foundation which is a vehicle for girls to gain self-esteem and confidence, with girls' empowerment camps.” Morgan helped redefine the sport, leaving a legacy that lives on in others who dare to dream because she showed them what was possible. It may be the end of an era and the changing of the guard, but the passion remains.

Bayern Munich coach Vincent Kompany announced the decision to rest first-choice veteran goalkeeper Manuel Neuer for the upcoming Bundesliga clash. The decision to drop him from the starting lineup means that 22-year-old understudy Jonas Urbig will get an opportunity to show he can be counted upon despite Neuer still going strong.

Eva Gaetino Called Up from U-23 WNT Training Camp to Join USWNT Roster
Source: US Soccer    Published: 2025-10-24 14:22:49

Get unrivaled matchday access ATLANTA (Oct. 24, 2025) – Defender Eva Gaetino, who was participating in U.S. Under-23 Women's National Team Training Camp this week outside of Philadelphia, has been called up to the U.S. Women's National Team roster and will join the U.S. camp ahead of the final two matches of the FIFA window. The USA will face Portugal on Sunday, Oct. 26 at Pratt & Whitney Stadium at Rentschler Field in East Hartford, Conn. (4 p.m. ET on TNT, truTV and HBO Max in English, Universo and Peacock in Spanish and on the radio on Westwood One Sports) and then will take on New Zealand in Kansas City, Mo., on Wednesday, Oct. 29, in the team's first-ever match at CPKC Stadium (8 p.m. ET / 7 p.m. CT, on TNT, truTV and HBO Max in English on Universo and Peacock in Spanish and on the radio on Westwood One Sports and FDP Spanish radio). The match in Connecticut will be presented by Volkswagen. U.S. head coach Emma Hayes had originally named 26 players for this camp, but with forward Trinity Rodman having to withdraw due to injury, a roster spot opened up and it has now been filled by Gaetino. The 22-year-old Michigan native was with the USA for the 2024 SheBelieves Cup, but did not see action, and then earned her first and thus far only cap in a 90-minute performance against Argentina on Oct. 30, 2024. “This is the epitome of the value of the U-23 program,” said USWNT head coach Emma Hayes. “We have the U-23s training at the same site as the National Team, so we are easily able to call a player up and it's important for the U-23s to know how much we value them. Eva is a player who has been in with the full team and in with the U-23s, but also out of both teams. No players' journey is the same and certainly no one's career takes a linear path. We gave Eva some pointed feedback over the past year, and she went back to her club, worked every day to get another chance at a call-up, and put into action things we wanted to see in her. She's the most WNT-ready player in this U-23 camp so she'll be a good addition to our training camp roster for the last week.” The 5-foot-11 central defender out of Michigan is in her third season, but second full season, with Paris Saint-Germain in France's Première Ligue after a banner college career at Notre Dame. October Matches vs. Portugal & New Zealand GOALKEEPERS (3): Claudia Dickey (Seattle Reign FC; 2) Mandy McGlynn (Utah Royals; 4), Phallon Tullis-Joyce (Manchester United, ENG; 3) DEFENDERS (9): Jordyn Bugg (Seattle Reign FC; 2/0), Emily Fox (Arsenal FC, ENG; 67/1), Eva Gaetino (Paris Saint-Germain; 1/0), Lilly Reale (Gotham FC; 2/0), Tara McKeown (Washington Spirit; 8/0), Avery Patterson (Houston Dash; 6/1), Emily Sams (Orlando Pride; 5/0), Emily Sonnett (Gotham FC; 110/2), Kennedy Wesley (San Diego Wave; 0/0) MIDFIELDERS (8): Sam Coffey (Portland Thorns FC; 38/4), Lindsey Heaps (OL Lyonnes, FRA; 167/38), Claire Hutton (Kansas City Current; 6/1), Lo'eau LaBonta (Kansas City Current; 2/0); Rose Lavelle (Gotham FC; 113/25), Olivia Moultrie (Portland Thorns FC; 9/2), Jaedyn Shaw (Gotham FC; 26/8), Lily Yohannes (OL Lyonnes, FRA; 8/1) FORWARDS (6): Michelle Cooper (Kansas City Current; 8/1), Catarina Macario (Chelsea FC, ENG; 24/11), Yazmeen Ryan (Houston Dash; 12/2), Emma Sears (Racing Louisville; 8/1), Ally Sentnor (Kansas City Current; 12/4), Alyssa Thompson (Chelsea FC, ENG; 22/3)

Kasey Keller Says USMNT Must Rekindle Fighting Spirit Ahead of World Cup
Source: rg.org    Published: 2025-10-24 11:00:41

Kasey Keller making a save at the 2006 World Cup (Photo by Christof Koepsel/Bongarts/Getty Images) Kasey Keller is a true U.S. Men's National Team legend. A four-time World Cup veteran, he was the starting goalkeeper in two of the four tournaments he played — in 1998 and 2006 — and delivered countless memorable performances across his 102 appearances for the United States. Among his international highlights are four Concacaf Gold Cup titles and a semi-final run at the 1995 Copa América in Uruguay, where the USMNT famously upset Argentina 3–0. Keller, who shared goalkeeping duties with Brad Friedel during that era, later delivered one of the greatest individual performances in U.S. Soccer history at the 1998 Gold Cup — a 1–0 win over Brazil, the only such victory in the program's history. He made ten saves that day, prompting Brazilian striker Romário to call it “the greatest goalkeeping performance” he had ever seen. Keller ranks second all-time among USMNT goalkeepers with 53 wins and recorded 47 clean sheets. His club career was equally distinguished, featuring successful spells in England, Germany, and Spain before finishing his playing days in MLS with the Seattle Sounders. Today, Keller serves as an ESPN pundit, appearing on ESPN FC and Fútbol Américas on ESPN+. In a sit-down interview with RG, Keller reflects on his transition from player to pundit and tackles some of the tougher questions surrounding U.S. Soccer — from the challenges faced by the so-called “Golden Generation,” to defining what success should look like at the 2026 World Cup, to why former stars of his caliber remain largely absent from the national team's leadership structure. – You've successfully transitioned from playing to punditry and even become a part-owner of a USL team. How important was it for you to find something meaningful to do after retiring, and how did that path into media and ownership come about — was it something that happened naturally, or did it take some time to figure out? – You know, it's tricky. A lot of players today earn great salaries, and those numbers keep growing generation after generation. But the reality is most players retire in their mid-30s. I was lucky — I almost played until my 42nd birthday, just a few weeks shy — but most are done much earlier. And when you think about it, how much money would you have to make in a short career to maintain the same lifestyle for the rest of your life if you retire at 34 or 35? So even from a financial standpoint, most players realize they'll need to do something after they retire. But it's not just about money — it's also about self-worth. When you've spent your entire life waking up with a purpose — training, preparing for a match, studying opponents — suddenly having nothing to prepare for can leave a big void. People say, “Oh, it must be great to retire and do whatever you want,” but after a while, that lack of focus can be tough. I was fortunate that I got to retire on my own terms. I could've played another year, but I chose to stop when I did. Most players don't get that choice — either the offers stop coming, or the body gives out. When I stepped away, I thought about what came next. If you want to stay in the game, there are really three main paths: coaching, front office, or media. For me, media made the most sense because of my family. When we moved back to the U.S., my kids started sixth grade — their fifth school in their fourth country. I didn't want to uproot them again. Working in broadcasting allowed me to stay put, keep them in school, and still stay involved in the game. I started with the Seattle Sounders' local broadcasts, which also included an ambassador role with the club. Then I signed a full-time contract with ESPN. What I loved about broadcasting after 20 years as a player was having some control over my schedule. Of course, if there was a match on the weekend, I couldn't just skip it, but during the week, I had flexibility — something I never had as a player. I remember when the Sounders' broadcasts were run by the Seahawks' media team. One Friday before a home game, I was invited to play in a charity golf event. Normally, Fridays were packed — we'd watch training, meet with players and coaches, and have a production meeting. I called my producer, Brian, and asked if I could miss the meeting. In my entire career, I'd only missed training for things like my kids' births or a medical emergency. And his response was, “Yeah, of course, just call me later and we'll go over what was said.” I was shocked — that kind of flexibility doesn't exist when you're playing. – Looking at U.S. Soccer now from a bit of distance, how do you see the program's overall progress since your playing days? Would you say it has continued to move forward, or has it stagnated — maybe even taken a step back in some areas? – I think it's a bit of both. There have been periods, especially after the U.S. qualified for the 1990 World Cup, where we probably overachieved in some of our results. And I think that early success created a false sense of expectation — that our progress would be steady and linear. People started thinking, “Okay, we've made it this far, so the next step must be the semifinals or the finals.” But that's not how international football works. There's a reason only a handful of countries — France, Germany, Brazil, Argentina — consistently win World Cups. It's not random. Some of that overachievement made people believe we'd reached that same level, when in reality, we were still developing the structure and depth needed to sustain it. I remember being part of a panel at the MIT Sloan Analytics Conference, and one of the questions was, “Why hasn't the U.S., with 350 million people, produced a Messi or a Ronaldo?” It reminded me of a story. Not long before that, my wife and I were on vacation in Costa Rica. As soon as we landed, people recognized me — staff at the airport, workers at the hotel — everyone wanted to talk about soccer: the U.S. team, Costa Rica, the World Cup. The sport is a national obsession there. But during that same trip, not a single American tourist stopped me to talk about football. And that, to me, sums it up. In most countries, football is the dream — every kid grows up wanting to play for their national team. In the U.S., there are a hundred different dreams. You can grow up wanting to be a football player, or a baseball player, or a snowboarder, or even a skateboarder like Tony Hawk. There's nothing wrong with that diversity, but it means our focus as a sporting culture is spread across so many directions. In places like Argentina or Brazil, it's simple — if you're not going to be a footballer, then you figure out what else to do. Here, it's the opposite. – When Mauricio Pochettino came in, he talked a lot about building a new culture within the national team. But it raises the question — what culture are we talking about changing? Because your generation had already built something strong. You guys competed well in Copa Américas, won Gold Cups, and were consistently successful. So do you think this idea of “changing the culture” overlooks some of what was already working before, or is it based on what he saw with this current squad? – Yeah, I mean, we got out of World Cup group stages, we competed well. I remember when I was at Leicester, one of my assistant coaches — a former Scottish international — used to give me a hard time whenever I missed a few club games for World Cup qualifiers. He'd say, “Why are you worried about that? You'll beat those teams easily.” And I told him, “Really? How many World Cup group stages has Scotland ever made it out of?” That was my point — what the U.S. achieved during that era wasn't automatic. We often overachieved compared to where we were as a footballing nation. That's part of managing — creating an environment where that hunger and competitiveness stay alive. What I really liked in these last few matches was that we finally started talking about football again — tactics, movement, missed chances — instead of questioning effort and mentality. That's real progress. I actually talked about this once with Thierry Henry. He told me, “When you played against Americans — club or country — you knew you had to match their effort. Maybe they weren't the best team technically, but if you didn't bring the same fight, you'd be embarrassed.” And he said recently he's noticed a bit of that slipping away. And he's right — we're not at a stage yet where pure talent alone can win games against top teams. Back when I was playing for Leicester against Manchester United or Arsenal, we couldn't just go out and play our football and hope for the best. We had to find ways to disrupt them, to fight, to get a result against superior sides. And that's what the U.S. always had — that determination to compete, to grind, and to find a way. – We're now seeing more U.S. players competing at top clubs and doing well, which is great. But when we talk about culture, I sometimes wonder about the difference between American players and, say, Uruguayans. In Uruguay, each new generation grows up trying to meet the standard set by those before them — like Godín following players such as Paolo Montero. There's a lineage to live up to. In the U.S., though, many of these players are the standard; they're the first to reach that level. Do you think that lack of an established tradition or benchmark could be part of the challenge when it comes to building a lasting football culture? – That's an interesting point, because while some of our players are now at big clubs, those clubs aren't what they used to be. The level of competition and expectations have dropped, and that changes the context. To be fair, many of these players have had very good individual seasons. But I've been there — I've had strong personal performances on teams that still finished mid-table. That's what's happening now: talented players doing well individually, but not necessarily leading top teams to success. And that's part of the issue. They've reached those big stages, but not necessarily during the club's strongest period, so they aren't yet establishing themselves as true stars competing for major titles. In earlier years, American players often didn't even get the chance to join top teams, simply because they were American. Now that they do, it's progress — but we're still waiting for someone to take that next step and really become a defining figure at the highest level. What's interesting is that while people call this a “golden generation,” there are also areas where we've gone backwards. There was a time when several American goalkeepers were starting regularly in the Premier League at the same time. That's not the case anymore. And yet, we keep hearing that we're producing more great players — but the results don't quite show that in some positions. And finally, just because a player performs well abroad doesn't automatically mean it translates to the national team. I always say, if someone has multiple nationalities, the key question isn't about talent — it's about identity. What are you? What do you feel you are? Because when it's 90 degrees, in tough conditions, playing in a difficult away qualifier, I need players who are 100% committed. If you're only choosing the U.S. because it's your best chance to play in a World Cup, that's not enough. – What is the real expectation of this USMNT team based on the body of work over the last six years? Two knockout round games at the World Cup? – I always look at the World Cup draw and ask myself: should the U.S. get out of that group? Sometimes, yes — sometimes, no. Take Qatar, for example. England were favorites to win the group, and when you look at the rest — Iran and Wales — you'd say the U.S. should finish second. That's a fair expectation. Now go back to Brazil. That group had Germany, Portugal, and Ghana — all very strong teams. In that case, it's hard to argue the U.S. should have advanced. They could, sure, but not that they should. That's where expectations get tricky. When people say it's a failure if the U.S. doesn't reach the quarterfinals, I ask: is the U.S. really one of the eight best teams in the world? No, not yet. To get that far, they'd have to beat teams that are better than them. It can happen — but it shouldn't be expected. Realistically, the U.S. is still somewhere between 20th and 30th in the world. – Then, given how the federation has danced around and many pundits have said that it's only about what happens at the World Cup, maybe doing well at the World Cup would only validate the immediate result and may make winning Gold Cups, Nations Leagues, or Copa Americas even less of a priority? – Yeah, I think it's about perspective. Three years out from a big tournament, no one really cares about every single player — like a sprinter or a swimmer — until they have a real chance to achieve something big, like winning a gold medal. Then people pay attention. The same goes for soccer. Missing one World Cup or qualifying campaign isn't the end of the world. Even historically strong countries face struggles, and it's about understanding the bigger picture. At the same time, the small wins matter. Winning Gold Cups, for example, is important because it builds a winning culture. The only way to create a culture of winning is by actually winning. And I've seen that firsthand — we've won with our best team and with mixed squads, and in both cases, players stepped up and grew from the experience. I also believe in putting a team on the field that can win every game. You can't rotate players just for the sake of giving everyone a chance in friendlies — those matches often don't reflect the true strength of the team. World Cup qualifying is different because it forces you to play the players who matter. The challenge in recent years has been too many meaningless matches, constant rotation, and coaching changes. Every time a new coach comes in, they expand the net to see everyone, which makes the process feel disjointed and false. It's hard to build momentum or culture in that environment. – Why haven't players like you or an Eddie Pope or other past USMNT stars transferred into coaching youth national teams, like say former players do with Argentina or Uruguay? Why has US Soccer closed the door on players who once defended the crest of the US? – I'll tell you a good story. Jürgen Klinsmann wanted to bring in some new talent and called me to ask if I could step in as the goalkeeping coach for a Gold Cup. At the time, I was broadcasting, and my contract had a clause that if I missed matches, my pay could be affected. I told him, “Jürgen, I can't commit without checking with the club.” The Sounders and Seahawks thought it was a great idea — having their local broadcast analyst on the national team was excellent exposure. So I called Jürgen back and said, “The club's fine with it, but here's what I'll be giving up to make it work. I'm not looking to make more money — I've been on four World Cup teams — but I shouldn't lose money to coach in the Gold Cup.” Jürgen said, “That's a fair point. I'll bring it up with U.S. Soccer.” A short time later, he came back and said, “U.S. Soccer won't cover it.” I told him, “I'm sorry, but I'm sticking to this. I'm not going to lose money to work for U.S. Soccer.” I called him and told him, “I will never do that again.” If U.S. Soccer doesn't value me enough to make up the difference after what I've given to the program, people hesitate to get involved. Former USMNT goalkeeper Kasey Keller sat down with RG and spoke about his memorable experience playing for Milwall, one of the most passionate clubs around. RG spoke to Jerome Opoku about recovering from an ACL injury, playing in the Süper Lig, and helping Ghana qualify for the World Cup. RG spoke to Renato Paiva about engineering Benfica's academy, being sacked by Botafogo after beating PSG, and plenty more in an exclusive interview. From coaching U.S. Soccer's youth teams to helping Nashville SC lift their first-ever trophy, Michael Nsien is making his mark on the technical side of the game. Rated 4.5 out of 5 Review us on Never miss an insight Subscribe to our weekly newsletter to get the most relevant insights on sports entertainment. Copyright © 2025 RG. WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Kasey Keller Says USMNT Must Rekindle Fighting Spirit Ahead of World Cup
Source: rg.org    Published: 2025-10-24 11:00:41

Kasey Keller making a save at the 2006 World Cup (Photo by Christof Koepsel/Bongarts/Getty Images) Kasey Keller is a true U.S. Men's National Team legend. A four-time World Cup veteran, he was the starting goalkeeper in two of the four tournaments he played — in 1998 and 2006 — and delivered countless memorable performances across his 102 appearances for the United States. Among his international highlights are four Concacaf Gold Cup titles and a semi-final run at the 1995 Copa América in Uruguay, where the USMNT famously upset Argentina 3–0. Keller, who shared goalkeeping duties with Brad Friedel during that era, later delivered one of the greatest individual performances in U.S. Soccer history at the 1998 Gold Cup — a 1–0 win over Brazil, the only such victory in the program's history. He made ten saves that day, prompting Brazilian striker Romário to call it “the greatest goalkeeping performance” he had ever seen. Keller ranks second all-time among USMNT goalkeepers with 53 wins and recorded 47 clean sheets. His club career was equally distinguished, featuring successful spells in England, Germany, and Spain before finishing his playing days in MLS with the Seattle Sounders. Today, Keller serves as an ESPN pundit, appearing on ESPN FC and Fútbol Américas on ESPN+. In a sit-down interview with RG, Keller reflects on his transition from player to pundit and tackles some of the tougher questions surrounding U.S. Soccer — from the challenges faced by the so-called “Golden Generation,” to defining what success should look like at the 2026 World Cup, to why former stars of his caliber remain largely absent from the national team's leadership structure. – You've successfully transitioned from playing to punditry and even become a part-owner of a USL team. How important was it for you to find something meaningful to do after retiring, and how did that path into media and ownership come about — was it something that happened naturally, or did it take some time to figure out? – You know, it's tricky. A lot of players today earn great salaries, and those numbers keep growing generation after generation. But the reality is most players retire in their mid-30s. I was lucky — I almost played until my 42nd birthday, just a few weeks shy — but most are done much earlier. And when you think about it, how much money would you have to make in a short career to maintain the same lifestyle for the rest of your life if you retire at 34 or 35? So even from a financial standpoint, most players realize they'll need to do something after they retire. But it's not just about money — it's also about self-worth. When you've spent your entire life waking up with a purpose — training, preparing for a match, studying opponents — suddenly having nothing to prepare for can leave a big void. People say, “Oh, it must be great to retire and do whatever you want,” but after a while, that lack of focus can be tough. I was fortunate that I got to retire on my own terms. I could've played another year, but I chose to stop when I did. Most players don't get that choice — either the offers stop coming, or the body gives out. When I stepped away, I thought about what came next. If you want to stay in the game, there are really three main paths: coaching, front office, or media. For me, media made the most sense because of my family. When we moved back to the U.S., my kids started sixth grade — their fifth school in their fourth country. I didn't want to uproot them again. Working in broadcasting allowed me to stay put, keep them in school, and still stay involved in the game. I started with the Seattle Sounders' local broadcasts, which also included an ambassador role with the club. Then I signed a full-time contract with ESPN. What I loved about broadcasting after 20 years as a player was having some control over my schedule. Of course, if there was a match on the weekend, I couldn't just skip it, but during the week, I had flexibility — something I never had as a player. I remember when the Sounders' broadcasts were run by the Seahawks' media team. One Friday before a home game, I was invited to play in a charity golf event. Normally, Fridays were packed — we'd watch training, meet with players and coaches, and have a production meeting. I called my producer, Brian, and asked if I could miss the meeting. In my entire career, I'd only missed training for things like my kids' births or a medical emergency. And his response was, “Yeah, of course, just call me later and we'll go over what was said.” I was shocked — that kind of flexibility doesn't exist when you're playing. – Looking at U.S. Soccer now from a bit of distance, how do you see the program's overall progress since your playing days? Would you say it has continued to move forward, or has it stagnated — maybe even taken a step back in some areas? – I think it's a bit of both. There have been periods, especially after the U.S. qualified for the 1990 World Cup, where we probably overachieved in some of our results. And I think that early success created a false sense of expectation — that our progress would be steady and linear. People started thinking, “Okay, we've made it this far, so the next step must be the semifinals or the finals.” But that's not how international football works. There's a reason only a handful of countries — France, Germany, Brazil, Argentina — consistently win World Cups. It's not random. Some of that overachievement made people believe we'd reached that same level, when in reality, we were still developing the structure and depth needed to sustain it. I remember being part of a panel at the MIT Sloan Analytics Conference, and one of the questions was, “Why hasn't the U.S., with 350 million people, produced a Messi or a Ronaldo?” It reminded me of a story. Not long before that, my wife and I were on vacation in Costa Rica. As soon as we landed, people recognized me — staff at the airport, workers at the hotel — everyone wanted to talk about soccer: the U.S. team, Costa Rica, the World Cup. The sport is a national obsession there. But during that same trip, not a single American tourist stopped me to talk about football. And that, to me, sums it up. In most countries, football is the dream — every kid grows up wanting to play for their national team. In the U.S., there are a hundred different dreams. You can grow up wanting to be a football player, or a baseball player, or a snowboarder, or even a skateboarder like Tony Hawk. There's nothing wrong with that diversity, but it means our focus as a sporting culture is spread across so many directions. In places like Argentina or Brazil, it's simple — if you're not going to be a footballer, then you figure out what else to do. Here, it's the opposite. – When Mauricio Pochettino came in, he talked a lot about building a new culture within the national team. But it raises the question — what culture are we talking about changing? Because your generation had already built something strong. You guys competed well in Copa Américas, won Gold Cups, and were consistently successful. So do you think this idea of “changing the culture” overlooks some of what was already working before, or is it based on what he saw with this current squad? – Yeah, I mean, we got out of World Cup group stages, we competed well. I remember when I was at Leicester, one of my assistant coaches — a former Scottish international — used to give me a hard time whenever I missed a few club games for World Cup qualifiers. He'd say, “Why are you worried about that? You'll beat those teams easily.” And I told him, “Really? How many World Cup group stages has Scotland ever made it out of?” That was my point — what the U.S. achieved during that era wasn't automatic. We often overachieved compared to where we were as a footballing nation. That's part of managing — creating an environment where that hunger and competitiveness stay alive. What I really liked in these last few matches was that we finally started talking about football again — tactics, movement, missed chances — instead of questioning effort and mentality. That's real progress. I actually talked about this once with Thierry Henry. He told me, “When you played against Americans — club or country — you knew you had to match their effort. Maybe they weren't the best team technically, but if you didn't bring the same fight, you'd be embarrassed.” And he said recently he's noticed a bit of that slipping away. And he's right — we're not at a stage yet where pure talent alone can win games against top teams. Back when I was playing for Leicester against Manchester United or Arsenal, we couldn't just go out and play our football and hope for the best. We had to find ways to disrupt them, to fight, to get a result against superior sides. And that's what the U.S. always had — that determination to compete, to grind, and to find a way. – We're now seeing more U.S. players competing at top clubs and doing well, which is great. But when we talk about culture, I sometimes wonder about the difference between American players and, say, Uruguayans. In Uruguay, each new generation grows up trying to meet the standard set by those before them — like Godín following players such as Paolo Montero. There's a lineage to live up to. In the U.S., though, many of these players are the standard; they're the first to reach that level. Do you think that lack of an established tradition or benchmark could be part of the challenge when it comes to building a lasting football culture? – That's an interesting point, because while some of our players are now at big clubs, those clubs aren't what they used to be. The level of competition and expectations have dropped, and that changes the context. To be fair, many of these players have had very good individual seasons. But I've been there — I've had strong personal performances on teams that still finished mid-table. That's what's happening now: talented players doing well individually, but not necessarily leading top teams to success. And that's part of the issue. They've reached those big stages, but not necessarily during the club's strongest period, so they aren't yet establishing themselves as true stars competing for major titles. In earlier years, American players often didn't even get the chance to join top teams, simply because they were American. Now that they do, it's progress — but we're still waiting for someone to take that next step and really become a defining figure at the highest level. What's interesting is that while people call this a “golden generation,” there are also areas where we've gone backwards. There was a time when several American goalkeepers were starting regularly in the Premier League at the same time. That's not the case anymore. And yet, we keep hearing that we're producing more great players — but the results don't quite show that in some positions. And finally, just because a player performs well abroad doesn't automatically mean it translates to the national team. I always say, if someone has multiple nationalities, the key question isn't about talent — it's about identity. What are you? What do you feel you are? Because when it's 90 degrees, in tough conditions, playing in a difficult away qualifier, I need players who are 100% committed. If you're only choosing the U.S. because it's your best chance to play in a World Cup, that's not enough. – What is the real expectation of this USMNT team based on the body of work over the last six years? Two knockout round games at the World Cup? – I always look at the World Cup draw and ask myself: should the U.S. get out of that group? Sometimes, yes — sometimes, no. Take Qatar, for example. England were favorites to win the group, and when you look at the rest — Iran and Wales — you'd say the U.S. should finish second. That's a fair expectation. Now go back to Brazil. That group had Germany, Portugal, and Ghana — all very strong teams. In that case, it's hard to argue the U.S. should have advanced. They could, sure, but not that they should. That's where expectations get tricky. When people say it's a failure if the U.S. doesn't reach the quarterfinals, I ask: is the U.S. really one of the eight best teams in the world? No, not yet. To get that far, they'd have to beat teams that are better than them. It can happen — but it shouldn't be expected. Realistically, the U.S. is still somewhere between 20th and 30th in the world. – Then, given how the federation has danced around and many pundits have said that it's only about what happens at the World Cup, maybe doing well at the World Cup would only validate the immediate result and may make winning Gold Cups, Nations Leagues, or Copa Americas even less of a priority? – Yeah, I think it's about perspective. Three years out from a big tournament, no one really cares about every single player — like a sprinter or a swimmer — until they have a real chance to achieve something big, like winning a gold medal. Then people pay attention. The same goes for soccer. Missing one World Cup or qualifying campaign isn't the end of the world. Even historically strong countries face struggles, and it's about understanding the bigger picture. At the same time, the small wins matter. Winning Gold Cups, for example, is important because it builds a winning culture. The only way to create a culture of winning is by actually winning. And I've seen that firsthand — we've won with our best team and with mixed squads, and in both cases, players stepped up and grew from the experience. I also believe in putting a team on the field that can win every game. You can't rotate players just for the sake of giving everyone a chance in friendlies — those matches often don't reflect the true strength of the team. World Cup qualifying is different because it forces you to play the players who matter. The challenge in recent years has been too many meaningless matches, constant rotation, and coaching changes. Every time a new coach comes in, they expand the net to see everyone, which makes the process feel disjointed and false. It's hard to build momentum or culture in that environment. – Why haven't players like you or an Eddie Pope or other past USMNT stars transferred into coaching youth national teams, like say former players do with Argentina or Uruguay? Why has US Soccer closed the door on players who once defended the crest of the US? – I'll tell you a good story. Jürgen Klinsmann wanted to bring in some new talent and called me to ask if I could step in as the goalkeeping coach for a Gold Cup. At the time, I was broadcasting, and my contract had a clause that if I missed matches, my pay could be affected. I told him, “Jürgen, I can't commit without checking with the club.” The Sounders and Seahawks thought it was a great idea — having their local broadcast analyst on the national team was excellent exposure. So I called Jürgen back and said, “The club's fine with it, but here's what I'll be giving up to make it work. I'm not looking to make more money — I've been on four World Cup teams — but I shouldn't lose money to coach in the Gold Cup.” Jürgen said, “That's a fair point. I'll bring it up with U.S. Soccer.” A short time later, he came back and said, “U.S. Soccer won't cover it.” I told him, “I'm sorry, but I'm sticking to this. I'm not going to lose money to work for U.S. Soccer.” I called him and told him, “I will never do that again.” If U.S. Soccer doesn't value me enough to make up the difference after what I've given to the program, people hesitate to get involved. Former USMNT goalkeeper Kasey Keller sat down with RG and spoke about his memorable experience playing for Milwall, one of the most passionate clubs around. RG spoke to Jerome Opoku about recovering from an ACL injury, playing in the Süper Lig, and helping Ghana qualify for the World Cup. RG spoke to Renato Paiva about engineering Benfica's academy, being sacked by Botafogo after beating PSG, and plenty more in an exclusive interview. From coaching U.S. Soccer's youth teams to helping Nashville SC lift their first-ever trophy, Michael Nsien is making his mark on the technical side of the game. WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


The USWNT just gave its worst performance under Emma Hayes. What went wrong against Portugal?
Source: The New York Times    Published: 2025-10-24 10:00:49

Log in Subscribe Now Region Search Top News Podcasts Connections: Sports Edition NBA gambling investigation NFL Home Teams Scores & Schedule Standings Fantasy NFL Odds NFL Picks NFL Draft Podcasts Scoop City Newsletter Playoff Simulator Trade Deadline MLB Home Teams Scores & Schedule Playoff Bracket Standings Podcasts The Windup Newsletter Fantasy MLB Prospects MLB Odds MLB Picks NCAAF Home
